review_title: Company with Unlimited Potential and Limited Managment
pros: Generous Benefits; Excellent Work / Life Balance; Flexible Hours; Travel (Limited); Visibility to Company Management
cons: Dysfunctional Management (Top --> Down); Lack of Accountability; Culture; Flat, Top Heavy Structure (Corporate)

pros: There is an excellent work/life balance in my position. The office is always friendly and everyone is willing to help should problems arise. The medical benefits are very lucrative as well as the bonus program for my position. Travel is not excessive but really gives you insight into the diversity of the company. The company seems to focus heavily on the employees as a "family", which creates a nice environment to work in. There are opportunities for advancement in most job fields. The pay is competitive in my position.
cons: Senior management really needs to be on the same page when it comes to "reaching across the aisle". There are 30+ people who have my title and we are broken down into 2 groups. Though our jobs are the same it seems as though the different managers try to create some kind of separation as if we are not on the same team or trying to accomplish the same mission.

review_title: Good company to work for if you know someone
pros: I started my career at this company with high hopes- fellow employees were great to work with, culture amazing and ability to move within the company fairly easy. Healthcare was amazing when i first started too.  Even got several raises too.
cons: It is impossible to move up at NOV unless you know someone or are related to someone. Or are willing to wait 10 15 years for your turn. Also, certain upper management are known to be horrible people and are given a free pass because they get the job done. Pay is much lower than other oil and gas companies for majority of employees and as a consequence many departments have issues remaining staffed (management also makes it a practice to understaff to save money). This means that more likely than not you will be underpaid and overworked. Depending on the location, this may or may not be coupled with either incompetent management or mean horrible bosses. You might get lucky and have a good boss though.

review_title: Not the company for high performers.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Good starting point for fresh-outs and few years of experience people. In general: good work environment, laid back culture, conscientious about work/personal life balance. If you have the connections with management, sure you'll have a good career in NOV. Job security.
cons: Limited career opportunity, even though it's a very large company, there's almost no cross divisional transfers. Lack of an objective performance evaluation system to promote the most capable personnel. Many people get promoted/given opportunity based on how the bosses like them (subjective). Salary all over the place, depends on employee's negotiation skills and leverage position. Average salary lower than industry's. Inefficient, don't know how to fix root cause's problem, everything wants to be solved with money, either increasing headcount or buying competitors. Falling behind the competition in the long run. There's a complete lack of synergy among all the divisions. Too much politics in the everyday work.

review_title: It is a so-so place to work for.
pros: Fairly easy to get hired/rehired. They do not fire employees over small mistakes or to cut down on their budget. In fact, they were the last company to carry out the mass layoff when the oil industry was declining. Plenty of overtime. Lower levels of management and regular employees usually have good interactions with everyone getting along and caring for each other. Benefits used to be very good but their health insurance plans started becoming too expensive (thanks to Obamacare initiative).
cons: Stressful work environment. Lower pay rates compared to similar companies in the industry. The higher up levels of management only focus on numbers, not the overall wellbeing of their employees. When there is a high demand, employees may be "required" to work crazy long shifts all week for several weeks to months. It's just bad management in general. Also, they would lie to your face even when they know you already knew the truth.

review_title: Good people/You are still just a number
pros:
1. Benefits are great
2. Most people are good people
3. Flexible hours
4. Plenty of work and then some
5. True to their bonus structure
cons:
1. You need to know someone in upper management to hang around
2. Don't reimburse school as said, even for experienced individuals continuing their knowledge
3. A lot of fresh faces straight out of school without experience, which makes adhering to any processes difficult
4. Constant state of flux and change to structure, sometimes people would start a new position and receive a project only to leave the position quickly and the project is passed down. Unable to be completed
5. Typical corporate environment even though it is masked. If it is time to make cuts, it is everyone for themselves except for the uppers and their friends

review_title: Scattered pieces of a very large and growing puzzle
pros: National Oilwell Varco is a good place to work depending on your specific location and your position in the abundant masses of acquisitions this big company is known for. Frankly, If you are a below middle management it isn't entirely that great. Benefits are on par with industry standards. Bonuses are fair, if you get them.
cons: This business enterprise is a top-heavy, acquisition hungry, enigmatic puzzle that hasn't quite got all its pieces sorted out yet. The management hierarchy here needs some really coarse tuning. Simply put, the company is in dire need of  skilled professionals who invite new ideas, and who actually take action on centralized goals that promote the wellbeing of the business and its employees. Unfortunately, the politics are abundant here at NOV, but hey that is typical of any work environment. Sometimes it can be overwhelming however, you just have to pick your fights wisely.

review_title: Overall a good company, Just don't rock the boat
pros: Good company, with an incredible Engineering Group, that strives for High Quality and On Time Deliveries.  A great group of employees for the most part, and they have a great equipment base.  With the right guidance they could produce product with an extremely high level of quality.
cons: Management gets in the way most of the time, they ask for your opinions, then do it there way.  NONE of the managers actually has any training in the areas that they control, so the people in charge of manufacturing has no clue of how to machine parts. They spend more time doing rework of discrepant parts, instead of fixing the problem.  Very hard to advance in the company unless you are a yes man.  Compensation - trying to run a California company on Texas wages

review_title: Great Benefits Political mid level management
job_title: Business Development Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits are great and a lot of good people front line supervisors and below. Flexibility if your supervisor likes you.
cons: Very political on the mid management level and up. If you are not in the click you will not get to that level and if you rub anyone the wrong way on that level and above you can quickly go from friend to foe. Still a lot of nepotism at some of the facilities. Some divisions are run better than others. Lacks diversity in mid level management positions and higher.

job_title: Field Service Technician in Houston, TX
pros:
Great team of techs to work with, lots of Vets.

Ability to make a lot of money if you want to work a lot of hours.

Supervisors and Managers were easy to work with, if you work hard and do what you're told, they are very willing to work with you on things like vacation, time off, and emergencies when they come up.
cons:
On call work is tough, especially if you want to plan time with the family, if you are single and just want to make a lot of money, this is the job for you.

Not too much training to be had, hopefully with the upturn in oil, more training opportunities will come up, but luckily the other techs are great about helping you out when you need it, and the supervisors are very helpful as well.

pros: Good benefits, plenty of time off (only if you're an office worker), you don't have to worry much about job security.
cons: Pay is lousy compared to other companies, management is lax, you aren't recognized or rewarded for your efforts so it's hard to stay motivated, and communication from superiors is horrible. The "next generation" managers in training are so underprepared and unknowledgeable that's it's not even funny, and they come in late/leave early/take extended vacations every chance they get, while leaving the old tired employees to do more work than ever. The plant workers rarely get any time off, even around the holidays, and the people who really deserve vacation never get it.

review_title: Many Changes some good some not
pros:
Huge Market Reach 
If you can politically connect you are golden 
Many different opportunities 
slowly cleaning house
cons:
The stability is gone
slightly below market wages
politics are getting out of control 
corruption, including senior management firing

job_title: Too Many Roles to List! in Cedar Park, TX
pros: Work Life Balance, Laid Back workplace, Good resume filler or coast to retirement option.
cons: Good Old Boy Mentality, unqualified people get promoted all the time, it's all about who you know, not what you know.  Management changes direction depending on who is at the helm, leads to a chaotic environment with constant change.  Processes are not well defined and on the job training can be disorganized, which creates levels of employees who are completely unaware of how things are supposed to work.  This creates a very disorganized and reactive environment.  Company knowingly pays lower than market rate due to the prime location.

job_title: Land Business Applications Manager in Houston, TX
pros: My personal team prior to layoff was great.
cons: Poor market conditions demand change but unlike past drops, the current management at NOV responded poorly. NOV use to be a place that while you may not get paid well you still wanted to be because of the people and management. Change in leadership in past years has lead to sneaky, back stabbing behaviors all to strive to meet impossible numbers. NOV went from being people & customer based to fear & number based.

job_title: Corporate Distribution Services in Houston, TX
pros:
Strong coworkers - I've met admirable people with extremely varied skill sets
great management - visionary, growing the company, communicating the vision, thinking about the future by hiring high-potential individuals on all levels (including college grads) 
-great work environment and company culture - Senior VP's always have their door open, go to happy hour with everyone else.
-employee oriented - if you perform, management will keep you interested. There are lots of young people with really exciting careers. If you want to work abroad, you can. If you want to be in the US, you can do that as well. If you're interested in working for a different group, just speak up. As long as you perform, you make your own career. Working with different groups is encouraged to learn about the business.
cons: Disconnect between divisions (Rig Solutions, Downhole, Distribution, Mission, Tuboscope, Brandt, Grand Prideco, etc)

pros: Coworkers... the people you spent more time than your family at home. Those people out on the floor and in the office were the ones that made it worth it all. The majority of them were willing to teach you the correct way and help you understand what you were trying to learn.
cons: Upper management was never willing to take time to appreciate the commitment, dedication, and acknowledge the worker who made them look good. There was no employee recognition for working late Fridays, weekends, and coming in on call to make it work to make sure the job was not missed. Outside sales were very greedy, self-centered, and manipulating. Even when they gave out t-shirts or hats, they did it out of spite and made us fight tooth and nail against each other which started jealousy, hate, and betrayal. We didn't have Christmas parties, bonus, or awards.

pros: I was at this position for 3 years. I was able to learn a lot about the industry and the components that go into building oil equipment. There were people willing to help me grow and learn since I didn't have a background in the industry. They offered a fair starting pay. Once I was comfortable working on my own I was free to do so with not too much of someone looking over my shoulder.
cons: Starting with no experience, they do give you a fair wage but it seems they are very unlikely to increase your pay by very much year to year. They also are not consistent with the pay they gave to other employees working in the same position with the same amount of experience. Communication was lacking in some areas of the company and it was sometimes difficult to get  what you needed in a timely manner without bugging someone constantly. Also there didnt seem to be much room for promotion with there being many senior project managers who wouldnt be moving on for sometime.

review_title: Depends on the Division of NOV you are in.
pros: Internal job transfers are fairly easy.  Work pace is not pressured.  On Call schedule varies depending on how many sales people you have working at a given branch.  Most all of their service end / rental divisions pay quite well and treat their employees fairly well.
cons: Lack of accountability.  Even when it came to upper management, it seemed as though people just turned a blind eye to a lot of issues that needed to be addressed.  One past worker got drunk and wrecked a work truck and then applied for a store manager position / transfer and it was accepted!    Depending on what division of the company you worked for, it seemed there was a wide range when it came to whether or not people cared if they got your business.  Their smith fiberglass division was especially bad.

job_title: Spray Rig Operator in Houston, TX
pros: There is nothing good here unless you are really dumb and don't have any skill, and were good at using your phone in school when you weren't suppose to.
cons:
Despotism, management play favorites
Literally 12 hr shifts, don't give a hoot about personal affairs 
They preach quality, but at the end of the night it's all about quantity this is gonna bite these ppl in the butt later I saw so many improper things being sent to the field
Everyone takes a break like 20x a shift, maintenance crew is lazy and expect for you to know how to fix the machines.
Don't make friends here
I hate this place, I hope I never work for a company that doesn't value their employees, I was literally told by the company shop supervisor in a meeting that we are indispensable. 
The supervisors don't know about anything, they fire hard workers and bring in temps and have temps train temps, nothing is ever learned correctly and fully.
Old machines etc..the list can go on.
Don't recommended working here, but looks good on your resume. Use this place as a stepping stone to something better.. there is something better trust me..

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Houston, TX
pros: There is so much opportunity at this organization to advance in your career if you are willing to work hard. I've been very lucky to get to be in multiple different positions during my time here, some of which I was not qualified for when I started, but they love to promote from within and took the time to train me up. I would also say that, for the most part, managers tend to be flexible and work with you in regards to your scheduling.
cons: Due to the downturn in O&G, there have been a lot of layoffs and perks that have been suspended for the time being (hopefully they bring these back after we get out of it). They typically pay at mid-market so if making money is your most important career aspiration, this is probably not the place for you.

pros: NOV has great financials as a company and is presently in transition to become a technology innovator within our business segment.  Career options are vast and employees encouraged to look within NOV for career growth.  The benefits from health, vacation, and bonus structure are excellent.
cons: NOV has grown through acquisition over the years which tends to make the company feel like a corporation made up of 100's upon 100's of small companies.  The company has been standardizing processes and company business systems over the last few years to address the issue and provide a more cohesive company and culture.  To some extent the current mix of different cultures and vast business units make the company feel somewhat like a home grown company that the employees are helping build.  For some of us that is the attraction of NOV.

pros: Decent salary for employees and nice bonus plan when goals are met. Promotes from within the company as much as possible.
cons: Men are allowed to say anything without any without any repercussions. They physically threaten other employees, yell, curse and blatantly break rules set in place. Managers will curse you for doing your job and discuss sexual acts openly in the lunch room. At any point if you defend yourself they tell the HR manager and you are reprimanded. Even after being provided proof of what male employees have done she states that she isn't concerned with what they did. Employees know and talk about her actions but are scared to report her. A female executive has commented that the HR manager is a bully and harassed employees but stated she can't report her and become her next target. The HR manger also is known for twisting statements to make them what she want and has physically put her hands on employees in a threatening manner.

review_title: On the low end of the pay scale
pros: They are great at understanding that family comes first, therefore vacation requests and days off are never a problem, provided that you have them available. They reimburse your college tuition at the end of the semester but you must pay for it up front first and you must have a C or better in all classes. Health insurance is priced comfortably and 401k is easy to set up.
cons: Low pay is the biggest con, even for those who have been with the company for 5+ years. Few or no employee reviews or assessments and no promising career in general, especially for new grads. Low bonus pay, even when quarterly profits are impressive, especially for hourly employees. Average age for employees at our location is about 45, the newer generation looks around for a better offer pretty quickly. A lot of people have been quitting at our location lately.

pros: Very intelligent and diverse workforce. Lots of knowledge and history in the oilfield. Enjoy my team and make significant contributions to NOV.
cons: Use to have great benefits with Cigna, changed to Blue Cross Blue Shield in the downturn with average benefits. Three years into the downturn and have not seen a bonus, pay increase, or any incentive. Difficult to install change because of how big NOV is and how many rounds of approval needed. Company culture has gone down since downturn. The environment is very depressing and job does not feel secure even the market shows progress.

pros: If you care about having a good work/life balance and strong benefits, NOV is a good company for you. The company treats you like a human being and most departments are good about being flexible with your personal life. The company also does a lot of hiring from within, which makes it easy to jump around the company if you aren't sure exactly what you want to do.
cons: Because this is a company focused on people, there are a lot of people at the company who should not be. It takes a lot for someone to get fired here (which can be a pro if you are lazy) but for people who actually work hard it is incredibly frustrating. The salary compensation is also terrible for the industry. They are not good about giving raises even with promotions and it takes a long time to make decent money.

pros:
NOV is a huge company and has the great benefits to go along with it. 

There is a large group of new engineers to drive innovation and a good core group of older engineers to provide guidance. 

My group has a commitment to excellence. 

I thought about leaving for more money but I couldn't find a company that had products I would be proud to be involved in had the same benefits or where I would have the same level of responsibility.

Good job security. 

Top level management is really good. Very strong company going in the right direction.
cons:
The company is divided up into so many groups and divisions it is hard to know what is going on in the company an where other opportunities might be.

The pay is no better than OK

Bonus is a little below average for oil industry.

Middle management can get bogged down.

pros: Benefits are good. Nothing else to say here.
cons: Atrocious work environment. Uneducated management promoted through the 'friends and family' program. Safety equipment is a secondary consideration (dusk masks in a dusty environment? Meh, we'll  get more next week). Management can not be trusted continuously bends the truth or lies outright. Time clock is adjusted by management according to their personal feelings. Work/life balance isn't even considered, if they want something, they take it; last minute scedule changes? You bet, happens every week when they feel like it. Pay is one of the lowest in the market and raises are lied about so as to avoid giving them in accordance with company policy, all to protect the bonus checks of upper management. Worst company i've ever born witness too.

pros: Large company with a huge network of subdivisions and potential opportunities across the globe.  Great infrastructure and tools to support employee and business needs.  Great bonus structure.
cons:
100% oil and gas focused, even when dealing with non O&G business units.  Poor recognition of product-level brand names "Everything is NOV".  CEO and regime change have changed the focus from aggressive growth to wait and see tactics.  Minor decisions in operating the business go many layers up in the organizational structure, and seem to spin around and change on a daily basis.  Very rattled by softening market conditions yielding a clear lack of direction at all organization levels.  
Bonus structure is dictated by high-level performance with no individual contribution component.  Bonus structure is good but merit increases are completely unstructured.

pros: good work environment, caring management
cons: There have been no raises in 5 years for office employees!?! Union workers are not subject to this, and would never put up with it. From what I have been told, this is the policy of NOV and the oil industry in general. I don't buy this, and as a result of the lack of raises many good employees have left the company. NOV bought out Chemineer/Robbins and Myers about 5 years ago, and this wasn't the policy previously. The only way to get a raise is to be promoted, and there is very limited opportunity for this. Often, they don't promote from within the organization, so loyalty is not being encouraged.

pros:
Being one of the biggest manufacturing companies in the oilfield, there are plenty of opportunities to expand your career path on a global scale. There are also a lot of opportunities to travel and see different parts of the world that most other companies would not be able to offer. 

Being a big company, it can withstand market downturns better than most other companies, thus there is more job security in a crashing market.
cons:
Being a big company, employees base salaries are typically on the low end of the average benchmark. 

With NOV's latest restructure, they broke up a lot of the smaller divisions and merged them all into 3 giant divisions. This evaporated a lot of the personable aspects of working for NOV and made it truly feel like working for a big corporation.

pros: There are a lot of good people in this company. Ones that care about each other, and there are a lot that are always willing to help.
cons: The HR.... I was with the company for many years. And was constantly mislead about my career and growth potential, lied to on multiple occasions so they could promote their friends. I was once told by an HR manager that "I don't work well with men".... If you are not part of their inner circle don't bother looking for growth or promotions. The don't understand recruiting in the slightest and believe that it is not a valuable aspect of Human Resources. Talent is not a priority to them and they want the cheapest person that can just do the job.  The culture and values have changed dramatically.  In my opinion not for the best.

review_title: NOV is a large company that operates liklike several independent companies.
pros: If you are interested in advancing your career or changing fields chances are NOV will give you the opportunity to do so. They also support professional development, but you may have difficulty advancing within the company.
cons: The company is very disorganized & dysfunctional. Management tends to prevent successful employees from promoting especially if it means they will leave the business group. Management blocks employees from transferring unless they have disciplinary issues.

review_title: Going downhill fast, Good, Bad and Ugly.
pros: Used to be a great company to work for for decades, not so much not anymore.
cons: Too many companies were acquired by NOV but never properly integrated, tons of inefficiencies. Career growth is mismanaged, e.g. failed mechanical engineers are promoted into business positions creating a plethora of incompetent mid-management "directors" and "VPs" running the business into the ground. Also, when a US company starts outsourcing and bringing a lot of Indians on board, you know the business is going south and cost-compete downhill.

review_title: Great Place for Experience & Work Environment
pros:
One of the best places I've ever worked in terms of Work Environment & People
> Managers tend to have an open door policy
> Work utilizes true engineering knowledge: calculations, CAD, etc.
> Combination of hands on and design experience
> Opportunity to work in different business segments all over the world
> Flexibility
cons:
> A fair amount below the APEGA average manufacturing engineering salary
> Work can sometimes seem repetitive, especially with some of the internal software
> Lower than average vacation days/ no flex days
> Have to be in the right group in order to advance well

pros: None, none, none and none
cons:
This company is not "global", in fact, it's a bunch of local companies sharing common name and email domain. Top management is there to skim the profit for the sake of shareholders. 
Neither is it "innovative leader", stuff they produce (for ex. offshore cranes) are technological relics plagued with problems. But they love that punchline and they write it everywhere.
A few words about:
Senior engineers - have done their best to complicate things in order to make themselves irreplaceable and are very intolerant of different opinions or fresh point of view. I have known quite a few engineers who quit their jobs out of frustration for not being able to improve on things.
Management, lower and mid level - incompetent and clueless in general, quick to point finger but they love those big SUVs. Back in 2014 they bragged about best profit year ever and then a year later they fired half of the staff in Norway me included.
HR - incompetent and rude.

I could go on about bad experiences but I am tired of typing.

review_title: Working for NOV has had for the most part had a very positive effect on my life.
job_title: Division Manager in Grande Prairie, AB
pros: There are many opportunities for employees to advance within this large orginization. There are numerous training modules such as inhouse training, online training and  outsides sources. The benefit package is great for a family or single person. There is a company matching  RRSP program ( company match increase with years of service ). The company encourges employees to use there vacation time
cons: A huge issue is hiring entry level employees in my area due to very low unemployment levels and a below industry starting wage. Activity in my area is like a bees hive, never stops. This situation is a hardship on all current employees.

review_title: Great Training, Nice People, Low Pay for the Industry
pros:
Great Training
People at the top have been around awhile
60,000 Employees world wide so you have a lot of room for growth
Great benefits
Company isn't going anywhere
Solid retention rates
cons:
People at the top have been around awhile and are stuck in their ways
Not very proactive - sometimes would rather wait for a problem to grow so they can be a hero
Some locations are very remote
With 60,000 employees, you're typically just a number
Your job happiness greatly depends on your division

pros:
Very professional, I was treated very well from day one
Autonomy, I was set to go on my job after only a few days of orientation and indoctrination. The only time a Manager intervened was if I had made a mistake I didn't know about or if I asked questions.
cons:
Parking was inadequate at the location I worked
Campuses are very far apart, a lot of driving if you frequent other work groups
Oil industry. Subject to the whims of OPEC
Cubicles. As a Creative I need an environment free of distraction so I frequently retreated into my headphones to work. That caused issues when people visited my space and tried to get my attention.

review_title: The Quintessential "Good-Ole Boy" Company.  Minorities Need Not Apply.
pros: Industry is doing well right now, so job security is not a great concern at this time.  There are some good people here but they are disappointed with management.  They are merely collecting a paycheck with no heart or spirit behind their jobs.  No other positives.
cons: This is the most unprofessional company I have ever worked for.  Constant reorganization due to upper management political games creates disillusionment for lower and mid-level employees.  Unless you are a Caucasian, your chances for leadership positions and/or promotions are extremely limited in this "good-ole boy" organization.  Promotions are based on who you know rather than skills and qualifications.  And because leadership positions are based on who you know rather than what you know, systems and processes are broken as most management tends to be incompetent.

review_title: Compensation was great, work environment ok
pros: Compensation and benefits are great.  Casual work environment, but can get too casual at times.  Worked with latest technologies, great learning environment.  Some extremely talented individuals.
cons: Huge re-org process underway after distribution split.  Responsibilities and scope of work changed after 2nd year; then my title was changed.  Not same job I was hired to do; have no idea what my actual job will look like in 6 months.  "Working" managers great at technology, bad people/team management skills.  Constant acquisitions makes fractured, piecemeal infrastructure with no consistency very difficult to support.  IT policies set on paper not practiced; no cohesion between departments or regions.  VERY lax and reactive attitude in IT silo.

review_title: Good step, but wouldn't stay here for long
pros: Yearly bonus is way above industry standard, expanding company and flexible working environment. The company is trying to consolidate the many small acquisitions it made through the past few years.
cons: Lack of direction, and lack of clear career path for employees. Also the company goes through a major reorganization every six to nine months. On the technology side the company does not offer a complete solution, it offers many small parts of the solution but lacks the momentum of a complete range of offering.

pros:
Insurance is the best at Houston location. They pay 100% while normal copays is all you pay for medical. Vision and dental are normal I would say.
Management is great at least in my department. They train you enough to get started and keep you up to date on new software training, and new practices. Supervisor is great and I'm glad to have him so I learn from someone that does my same job and understands my work.
Work load is good and steady which makes you feel important, useful, and part of a team.
This company, being so big, offers Great job security.
cons: Salaries are probably a little under the market but not by much.

review_title: A major percentage of the employees feel NOV is something different from their company/plant.
pros: I feel there is a good senior management heading the company. A lot of diversity as majority of 40,000 employees are outside of the US. Global travelling, solid balance sheet and of course for the next few foreseeable decades business will be good.
cons: The company is made up of so many different and acquired companies that a majority of the employees in these acquired companies still feel like they don't work for NOV. Consequently they have not been sold all of the companies practices and policies.

pros: Good base pay for most people, great benefits, very strong talent management and development resources.  Big company with small company feel to it.  Strategy of acquisitions has made it a major player in oil and gas manufacturing equipment and services
cons: It is oil and gas and cyclical in nature.  It seems to be a lot of little to medium size companies instead of one large company.  This could be seen as a pro though:)  But this is changing under new leadership, and NOV corporate is getting stronger and more efficient and using the cyclical nature of the business wisely to affect changes.  I don't expect this to be a "con" much longer.

review_title: NOV is great but not the PFT Fjords Team
pros: Best HR Policies and Employee Benefits: One of the best in UAE Market
cons: While NOV is undoubtedly great, the recently acquired Fjords Team in PFT is Horrible beyond words. Unrealistic working time; Extreme Work Pressure; Threatening/Warning Employees of Job Loss; Making Employees Insecure 24/7 and the People in Top are always trying to make an Efficient employee as a Scapegoat to coverup their own mistakes.

pros: If you’re good you’ll get lots of hours. You can gain a rather impressive skill set.
cons: If you’re good you’ll get lots of hours and never see your own bed, family or anything else you might value. I have put in nearly 84 hours a week for the last two years. Don’t expect a raise. Don’t expect your contribution to matter unless you screw up.

review_title: It has been a learning experience with willing teachers and semi-patient supervisors
pros: Great opportunity for advancement if you are willing to move around or get in the right place at the right time as they are a multi-national company and prefer to advance from within.
cons: So far they seem to pay on the low end to begin with and many sites are semi-remote due to the nature of the field.  In addition, while you get 12 paid holidays a year (on top of your vacation days) you rarely get them off as the oil fields are still working and they are a service business; so expect to work at least half of the major holidays if you wrk rural and get them off if your corporate.

review_title: Collect a paycheck and build a resume
pros: Standard benefits package and retirement plan, before the down turn there used to be things like tuition reimbursement and extra curricular training available (six sigma, management classes, etc) Also work was steady and somewhat hectic, great for taking home bigger checks. Whether you like working here will come down to the management you end up working for.
cons: Too much of a buddy system involved at all levels. Lax culture in engineering: working hours flexible as long as you get your work done
Good entry-level job.
Understanding and reasonable low-level managers and team leads
cons:
Poor technical training.

Poor opportunities for advancement within the company.
Laid off before those that were less competent and experienced.

review_title: NOV - Market Leader in Oilfield equipment
job_title: Supply Chain Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: Market leaders in drilling and supporting technology. Sound business strategy even during recession. Excellent overall backlog and continuing growth plan. Excellent products and growing market penetration, acquisitions, etc.
cons: Not competitive in terms of salary compared to market and competition (about 10-20% less than competition), Management does not care much about employees. Few managers control employee progress. High level politics affects employee morale and performance. Engineering & R&D is slow as employee retention is a problem due to low salaries. All facilities operate as separate entities, so lack of consistency in culture and outcomes.

pros: Progressive company that is willing to invest in new technologies.  Management now seems to look to the future with long term plans.
cons:
*About 10 years behind their competitors in technology.  
*Will ditch long term plans when the economy gets tough.  
*NOV depends on the oil and gas economy which is not stable for more than a few years at a time.

review_title: A good way to break into the oil industry for the first time.
pros: For my first professional job out of college I felt like they paid me very well in spite of having no professional experience up to that point.
cons: Because it is an oilfield services company business is directly tied to the ups and downs of oil prices. As a result, the company tends to over-hire when oil prices are high and then they lay off a lot of people when those prices drop.

pros: I enjoy working at NOV, the people are great to work with and there is a team atmosphere.  The benefits are about standard with other large organizations.  When the oil industry is in good standing, it is great to work here.  Your hours can be flexible as far as a start time to avoid the heavy traffic, so that is a benefit too.
cons: Right now they are downsizing quite a bit and closing facilities, good people are losing their jobs.  I understand the need to downsize to remain a viable company, but when they do this they do not downsize in management, so they are really top heavy.

review_title: NOV gave me a career not just a job
pros: My managers taught me as much as I was willing to learn.  They had faith in me and trusted me which I find refreshing.  I was promoted multiple times.  Benefits were awesome and I made life long friends within the organization.
cons: I was disappointed when the downsize happened in 2015.  Many great leaders were forced to take early retirement.  The new Management team didn't know me or my work ethics so all loyalty went out the window.  I was laid off after 13 years.   At one time we had 999 entities so it was quite challenging to navigate the company and I had very little work/life balance.  I was on call 24/7.

pros: It is a job.  You literally can be a completely non-productive employee and keep your job.
cons: Salary is not equal among similar positions within the company.  Management can be paid less than all the employees that report to the Manager.  Unethical decisions made by upper management.  For example, dealing with a victim who filed a harassment complaint by deciding to lay them off the very same day you tell them to their face that, "you are very sorry this incident occurred and it will be fully investigated."  Broken promises by management like a broken record.

review_title: A good place to gain experience in the Oil and Gas Industry
pros: Stable job situation; low micromanagement; wide range of products and services; Benefits are excellent and Vacation days afforded to new employees is the most I have seen anywhere;  Opportunity is there to learn and gain valuable experience in the Oil and Gas Services Industry
cons: Working environment is far too political; Salary is below what competitors pay; little opportunity to develop skills and move up in one's career.

review_title: Good company to work for before the oil price crash
pros:
Large interesting company with good possibilities of career progression when times were good and oil prices were still high.

A large variety of product lines to work with. Tasks are varied and often exciting.

Friendly co-workers and managers (depends on the department).

Average pay and benefits.
cons: Poor synergy between the various departments within NOV. Some divisions do their own thing and do not carry others along. This sometimes make it difficult to deliver a complete suite of products and services to clients. This also led to some departments within NOV hiring externally recruits while other departments were laying off workers. As a result, many talented workers were laid off when they could easily have been transferred to other departments that needed their expertise.

review_title: Good to gain experience but most management seems to be looking out for themselves
pros: Selective hiring process that weeds out most incompetent people but some still make it through. Makes work much easier when your not picking up others slack. Benefits start day 1 and all information is explained in orientation. For those working in production they provide prescription eyewear and steel toe boots
cons: standard corporate BS where some people become complacent and put others down to ensure their survival within the company.

review_title: Great People - Great Place to Work - NOV PCG WLY
pros:
There are a lot of things on the move at our company. The people are excellent and normally treat you like Family.
Leadership is getting better at our Division and there are many things in process to help NOV improve.
Like all companies, there is good and bad but just remember - the grass always appears greener on the other side.
Keep in mind what may make it greener - and try not to step in it. We are growing as an organization, and are very stable. Pete Miller (DNOW currently) was an excellent Leader with a Vision, one I believed in - we at NOV 
do miss him but Clay Williams may be more tactical which may work to NOV's and DNOW's advantage long term.
Both are excellent Leaders, and people. We are made up from the core companies and have grown thru both acquisition and modernization. This takes adding structure, organization and takes time. 
Looking forward to working with NOV long term, not interested in chasing a buck.
Yes we tend to pay a little less, but the benefits are good and the people are even better.
We are getting better every day. The old ERP is on the way out and we will have a better system. 

The Management in the last year has made more positive strides in the last year than the 5 previous.
Our Future is Bright!
cons:
We tend to hire less skilled people with degrees at lower rates, then they gain experience and move on.
Need more Design Engineering support - There is not enough time, to save time and money.
We are on the lower end regarding pay, benefits and bonus.
If you do not like your current position - look for something else - within NOV.
You will find your place.

pros: The benefits are good. The insurance and 401K is pretty good and they have a good number of  vacation days and holidays.
cons: Salaries are not competitive. When I started I made less than I did at my first engineering job 14 years before. Since I was contract I didn't get paid for holidays or sick days, When they hired me they paid me more, but I am still making much less than I did 10 years ago.

pros: Lots to do when it was busy. I made good money in previous years, and ran myself ragged with the available overtime some months.
cons:
Nothing to do when it was not. I spent weeks on end working in my little corner of the shop, wallowing in my own self-loathing and guilt, because I felt like I wasn't earning my keep if I wasn't on a ticket.

Cliquish teams. Unless you hunt, fish, follow NASCAR, Duck Dynasty,  and/or sports, nobody cares to associate with you.

Some days, the only thing I still liked about the job was the truck

job_title: Drilling Solutions Engineer in Casper, WY

job_title: Drilling Fluids Engineer in Amarillo, TX

review_title: Working for a large international company tied into Oil and Gas

review_title: Good benefits, low pay, and feels dead end due to lack of employee development.

review_title: It's a great Company to work for.

review_title: Okay Company, Good starting point to the industry

review_title: NOV a great company for long term investing of your future.

review_title: A company you don't want to leave but should you?
pros:
NOV is hands down the best company I've worked as an employee. A very laid back atmosphere that encourages you to share your opinions. They also encourage you to have a work/life balance which you can tell when the NOV tower starts turning into a ghost town even before 5pm. It is a very diverse company with people from all different kinds of backgrounds. A lot families and relatives work at NOV. People just love working here, I have not seen so many employees that been working for over 20 years at any other company. In addition, I have not sensed any bureaucracy and the managers are more of a mentor than a boss. I enjoy going to work everyday and appreciate what I bring to NOV is noticed. 

As far as benefits go, you get health insurance from BCBS of Texas and premiums are affordable. Dental, Vision, Life, Disability, Retirement 401k, etc. are all typical for a large company. Unlimited sick leave, 3 weeks PTO starting off, and standard US holidays (one almost every month). 

The facility (NOV Tower on Richmond) is good but had the potential to be great. Don't expect a full blown campus like other O&G companies. But there are perks, the food in the cafeteria is amazing and guest restaurants from all over town come in everyday so you have many options to choose from. It's highly secure and the building is very high tech. There are lounges everywhere and conference and hall rooms galore. The views from the top floors are beautiful from the full glass walls on the edge of the building.
cons: Working in finance & accounting, I know that as a business, NOV has not been very profitable in the last few years and I'm pretty sure you can guess why that is. Salaries and bonuses are decent but not as good as when O&G was doing well. And lastly, it is a bit hard to advance up the career ladder at NOV, why that is I don't know...This causes a lot of good people to leave, but the great thing is once you have NOV on your resume, you get scooped up really fast by another employer and pay is usually excellent.

job_title: Cash Applications Clerk in Houston, TX
pros: Long-established, multi-billion dollar global company more than a century old, with hundreds of locations worldwide (dozens of locations in the Houston area alone). Beautiful building at the NOV tower, where I worked (10353 Richmond Ave., Houston, TX 77042). Very good benefits, including a 401K plan with a company match. Even if you don’t contribute to your 401K for the match, the company will still invest 2% of your salary on your behalf, with the company’s own money. The company’s large size provides the chance to transfer into new job opportunities not afforded at smaller companies.
cons:
Because of the company’s massive size, it’s hit or miss when it comes to landing in a good department. I was hired a month before the O&G market dropped, so I worked in an environment of what seemed like constant change, company-wide as well as within my departments (layoffs, reorganizations, etc.). The company is made up of 3 different divisions that operate differently: Rig Systems, Wellbore Technologies, and Completion & Production Solutions (CAPS). I worked 2 different positions in CAPS and Rig Systems. Of the 2, I would say Rig was worse, probably the worst of the 3. The Rig division operates the most with a “bottom line” mentality, with little regard for its employees. It is also the division that provides the least amount of sick days (3 per year; CAPs provides 5 sick days per year). 

The second department in which I worked (in the Rig division) was run with a “do more with less” attitude. When I transferred to that department, there were always 4-5 members on my team. But when 2 team members left in the same month, that left only 2 of us to do all of the work. Upper management said we could manage fine with 2 people – wrong; my teammate and I grew tired, overworked & frustrated. On top of that, upper management was very stingy with overtime, despite our team being understaffed. We were promised a temp would be hired to help with research. That took 3 months to happen; 2 days before I resigned. In the 3 years that I worked at NOV, I learned many new skills, was “promoted” with additional job duties and a fancier job title, but never received a raise. This was a common practice, particularly in the Rig division.  Another Rig employee was promoted to manager and given a lot of additional work with no pay raise; she resigned a few months later. I finally realized the only way I was ever going to receive a raise was through a new job at a new company, so I eventually found a new job. 

The Rig department in which I worked had 16 employees. In the 16 months that I worked there, 10 people left; I was number 10. Some were fired, some resigned and 1 transferred, but it all adds up to a very high turnover rate for a department that size. My department also handled resignations rudely. When you put in your 2 weeks’ notice, as I did, you are quickly escorted by your manager to HR to complete a quick exit review, after which you are escorted off the premises the same day – like a fired or laid off employee. The only difference is that they pay you for the 2 weeks’ notice. Of all the numerous rules and policies that were discussed in that department, this practice was never mentioned. The other divisions don’t handle resignations this way. Overall, I don’t regret working for NOV, and there are better-run departments within the company. I do advise that if possible, try to find a job in the CAPS or Wellbore divisions.

review_title: If you want to move up, you have to move out or know someone.
pros: It's a big company that owns the oil field market.
cons:
You can see the trend in other reviews. Either the reviewer is young with little experience and likes NOV for the opportunity, or they're a bit older and complaining that you need to know someone to get advanced. NOV is the good ol' boy network on steroids. I worked for them for quite a few years before I finally got fed up and left. I also got several advancements, so this is not a sour grapes review.
NOV's customers absolutely hate them, and will go to any other vendor to try to get parts and supplies, given the chance. This means that NOV will eventually go out of business, if they get even a modicum of competition. They have avoided this by buying the competition, so far. The products are over-priced and under-supported.
Basically, the business model of NOV is to acquire a top-of-the-line company, put its leadership into a VP slot, and run off the experienced (read: higher-paid) engineers and designers then hire folks off the street or from their circle of friends to be the management group. They then run that product into the ground until their customers look elsewhere. If "elsewhere" starts to get any market foothold, then NOV buys them and repeats the process.
This model cannot be sustained in the long run. I would expect to see NOV selling off assets when the next downturn happens in the oil patch. Their customers will buy elsewhere for less as soon as they have the time to shop around. Right now, there is no time to go elsewhere, so the "one-stop-shop" of NOV gets the whole bid. When money becomes on par with time for projects, NOV will lose out. When money is more valuable than time on projects, NOV will plummet in sales. It is just a matter of time.
Part of the "other" this review asks for is the 6 month outlook. I selected "down," but only for the long-term outlook. I don't know if the next downturn will be in 6 months or a year, or more, but I do know that the oil patch goes through cycles, and only well-liked and customer-oriented companies make it through the downturns intact. NOV falls into neither category.

review_title: National Oilwell Varco is a company that needs to move into the 21st Century if they want to continue to compete!
pros:
National Oilwell Varco is a large, multi-national company with locations world-wide! As such, they are very stable an offer lots of opportunities for growth.  In the realm of oilfield service providers, they are quite competitive with the other "players" in the same realm. Here are some of the biggest pluses:

An above average benefits package
Job stability
A huge umbrella with lots of career opportunities at other company's under the umbrella
A decent bonus package
A flexible work schedule
Allowed time off when needed for family
cons:
As a two-edged sword, because NOV is a very large, multi-national company that has gobbled up others along the way, they now exist as a bunch of dis-jointed business groups that do not co-exist well with each other! There are way too many business processes & business tools that have been allowed to remain after acquisitions until now there is a big conglomeration of tools that don't communicate with each other & a bunch of non-working or non-existent processes. Also, management still lives too far in the past of the "good old boy" oil patch working era, still wanting to do things the same way they've always done them because that's the way they've always done them! That philosophy doesn't cut it in this day & age. Also, management needs to take a very, VERY hard look at salaries as they are not inline with the competition. Too much work & not enough reward make for an unpleasant working relationship! Major cons are:

Poor communication practices
Promotions to unworthy employees
Pay NOT COMPETITIVE
No defined career paths

Very little formal training to bring new hires up to speed and assume much of the knowledge of their product is widespread. Difficulty transitioning to new life cycle software. review_title: NOV is great to jumpstart your career but definitely not a long term opportunity

Accelerated Career (first few years only) - if you make the good connections with the leadership team and they see how hard you work/value produced , it is easy to make to a manager level in 5 years. Although quite frankly your title sounds more awesome than your actual job. I was a manager for 3 years but never had any direct people reporting to me. 

Health Benefits - Wow seriously this company has amazing insurance benefits, your co-pay with health providers are low and I remember going to the doctor every time I even had a sneeze! LOL!
cons: This place still has the "good old boys" mentality going around where I found people in a leadership team asking me to order in lunches because I was the only female in the meeting. Using terms like "he" for engineering jobs, operation managers was so common! Getting people to change here is ridiculously difficult! I graduated with an MBA and wanted to proposed changes to the leadership team and was basically told to "shut up and do your job". The pay was so low, they definitely believe in low cost and high volume. Last but not least, NOV acquires so many "mom and pops" and never ever streamline anything so it is typical to find a "mom and pop" out of Louisina/Texas operating under an S&P 500 header! There were things the company I worked for were doing that I felt like screaming because it was so backward!!
